subtitle: Have you ever heard of the Gospel of Judas...? This ancient text, excluded from the modern Bible,
offers intriguing references and clues suggesting that Jesus, also known as Yeshua,
may have been perceived as an extraterrestrial being from another dimension. While this idea
may sound blasphemous to modern Christianity, exploring such ancient texts can offer a deeper
understanding of Jesus or Yeshua's identity. For generations, Judas Iscariot has been seen as the
epitome of evil, a universal symbol of betrayal and treachery among believers. In Dante’s Inferno,
he occupies a special place in the third circle of hell, enduring eternal punishment. The biblical
gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John all condemn Judas as the one who betrayed Jesus,
selling him out to the authorities for thirty silver coins which would not make him nowhere
near a rich man. Some interpretations even suggest that Judas was in league with Satan,
such was the magnitude of his betrayal. However the gospel of judas gives a different perspective,
and many wonder today why it was taken out of the canonized bible by the Vatican.
The discovery of the Tchacos Codex, which includes texts from the Dead Sea Scrolls found in the 1970s
in Egypt, shed new light on Judas. This codex, believed to be translated from
ancient Greek to Coptic around the second century, contains various ancient texts,
including the Gospel of Judas. In 2006, the National Geographic Society released
the translated Gospel of Judas, sparking widespread interest in this previously
unknown text. Unlike the traditional gospels, this text portrays Judas not as a villain,
but as a close friend of Jesus who understood his mission better than the other disciples. According
to this gospel, Judas' betrayal was actually part of a plan orchestrated by Jesus himself to fulfill
his destiny and a necessary step in fulfilling a divine plan. According to this gospel, Yeshua,
also known as Jesus, asked Judas to hand him over to the authorities, as it was part of a larger
plan for Jesus's crucifixion and ultimate sacrifice for humanity. In this episode,
we'll refer to Jesus as Jesus, but it's important to note that his real name was Yeshua. Similarly,
many other names we know from the canonical Bible, like Mark, Luke, and John, are in actuality
English names and all of Jesus's disciples were illiterate and did not write the gospels.
However, the Gospel of Judas which was conjectured by gnostic believers from Jerusalem after Yeshua's
death was not accepted by Emperor Constantine when Christianity was seen as a Gnostic text,
part of a diverse range of beliefs that existed alongside early Christianity and
not the Christianity of the Roman Empire under the rule of Constantine. These Gnostic beliefs often
diverged from the Roman teachings of Christianity and spoke more on a spiritual notion and ancient
mysteries from Egypt. These were considered heretical by the Roman church and Constantine.
They believed that these alternative texts could confuse believers and dilute the true message of
Christianity. However, in the recent millennium, it was realized that Romans and Constantine
created their own version of Christianity mixed with paganism to control the population.
The Gospel of Judas was then officially rejected by early church leaders like Irenaeus,
who condemned it as heretical. They discarded and buried books that portrayed Judas as heroic,
preferring a more unified message where Judas was unequivocally seen as the betrayer. This decision
shaped the Christianity we know today, where Judas is vilified as the ultimate traitor.
In the officially recognized gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, Judas is depicted as
deceitful and greedy. In Matthew 26, Judas agrees to betray Jesus for thirty pieces of silver. Mark
14 and Luke 22 also describe Judas conspiring with the chief priests to betray Jesus. John 13
portrays Judas as the one who betrays Jesus after receiving a piece of bread from him.
In other Gnostic gospels such as the Gospel of Thomas, we’ve seen Jesus openly mock his disciples
or chastise them for their false prayers or insincere prayers. Specifically in Thomas, he is
seen to tell his disciples not to bother praying if they don’t really mean it, because it is their
spirit that will be judged in the end, not the words that they say unto God. The Gospel of Judas
states on a time where we see Jesus criticized his disciples when he finds them praying.
In fact..... the text tells us that Jesus laughs at them! We are told, “The disciples said to him,
‘Master, why are you laughing at our prayer? What have we done? This is what’s right.’ And
Jesus answered them, saying, ‘I’m not laughing at you. You’re not doing this because you want
to...... but because through this your God will be praised.’” Again, similar to the Gospel of Thomas,
Jesus finds humor in his disciples’ efforts to be pious and moral, and he actually calls them
out for it, for he knows they like many others are not praying for the goodness of others or
to honor their God, but only for themselves. Furthermore, Jesus seems to alienate himself
from them—or at least, from the idea that he is the son of God, for he refers to his disciples’
God as ‘your God’—suggesting that the disciples aren’t even praying to the right God anyway.
This confuses the disciples, as they attempt to confirm, ‘Master,
you..... are the Son of our God!’ And Jesus replies, ‘How do you know
me? Truly I say to you, no generation of the people among you will know me. Again,
Jesus continues to distance himself from his disciples. He questions not only their faith,
but also their intelligence and their intentions. When his disciples heard this, they started to
get angry... confused... and furious and in their hearts, they began to curse him silently.
The evening sky was painted with hues of dark blue as Yeshua and his twelve
disciples were in the secluded foggy garden of Gethsemane. A hushed silence enveloped them,
after what Yeshua also known as Jesus had said.
Yeshua, a figure of divineness and serenity upon his disciples, sat quietly and apart from the
group, his eyes reflecting towards the vastness of the night sky. Yeshua wore a white brownish robe,
with a white tunic. His disciples prayed and then watched him in silence with a mixture
of reverence and unease, sensing the weight of an impending revelation from him. Among them,
Judas stood quietly as well, his mind racing with thoughts.
Breaking the silence, Yeshua's voice, both gentle and commanding, filled the garden.
"Why are you troubled, my friends?" he asked, his gaze sweeping over the assembled disciples. "Your
prayers are hollow, uttered not from the depths of your hearts but out of habit and fear."
The disciples, caught off guard, exchanged anxious glances. Peter, ever the spokesman,
ventured to speak. "Master, we pray to honor you and the Father. Is that not right?"
Yeshua's eyes twinkled with a knowing sadness. "You pray to appease your own doubts,
Peter. True prayer comes from the spirit, not from the lips."
At this, a murmur of discontent rippled through the group, but Yeshua's attention was already
elsewhere. He turned to Judas, who stood slightly apart, his face shadowed by an inner turmoil.
"Come forward, Judas," Yeshua beckoned.
Judas hesitated, then stepped forward, unable to meet Yeshua's gaze directly. "I know who you are,
and where you come from," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "You are from the immortal
realm of Barbelo....... and I am not worthy to utter the name of the one who has sent you."
The other disciples were not listening to their conversation, Yeshua smiled.
"Let us Step away from the others," Yeshua
instructed Judas softly. "There are mysteries I must share with you,
secrets of the kingdom and my father that you alone can only understand. But know this:
the path you will walk with me now.... is fraught with sorrow and your heart will be heavy.
Judas nodded, his heart already heavy yet resolute. The two men moved deeper into the
garden, leaving the bewildered disciples behind. As they walked, the world seemed to fade away,
and Judas felt as though he were stepping into another realm entirely, one where time and space
held no sway. Yeshua at this moment, began to slowly glow with a angelic bright hue.
"Judas....." Yeshua began, his voice echoing through the ether,
"you have been chosen for a great and terrible purpose. The others cannot see what you see,
nor can they bear the burden you will carry. The events that are to unfold are
written in the stars, orchestrated by forces beyond this world."
Judas listened, his soul trembling under the weight of Yeshua's words. "What must I do,
Master?" he asked, his voice breaking with emotion.
Yeshua placed a hand on Judas's shoulder, his touch radiating warmth and reassurance. "You
must betray me," he said simply. "It is through your act of betrayal that I will
fulfill my destiny and bring salvation to humanity. You will be vilified,
condemned through the ages, but know that in doing so, you are serving a higher purpose."
Tears welled in Judas's eyes as he grappled with the enormity of his task. "I will be
remembered as a traitor," he murmured, "hated by all who hear my name."
Yeshua's eyes softened with a mixture of sorrow and admiration. "History will judge you harshly,
but the truth will remain hidden from the masses. Only you and I will know
the sacrifice you have made, the love and courage it took to play your part."
Judas said to Jesus, ‘Look, what will those who’ve been baptized in your name do?’ The
text continues that Jesus then answers, ‘Truly I say to you, this baptism done in my name
will destroy the whole generation of the human race among them from the ruler of the heavens,
for he will drag them to the works of error, and he will make them commit sin.’ This is perhaps
one of the most controversial points made in the Gospel of Judas. Jesus here tells Judas that those
who’ve been baptized in his name will have their entire generation destroyed and that the ruler of
the heavens will make them commit sin. This is a complete contrast to the New Testament, which sees
Jesus welcome people to be baptized and to walk in his name. Yet here,
Jesus tells Judas that those who follow him are only walking towards their doom.
He goes on to tell Judas, ‘Stop sacrificing which you have over the altar, since they are over your
stars and your angels and have already completed everything. Let them become ensnared before you,
and let them go 12 more generations. However, a baker cannot feed all creation under heaven.’
With this, Jesus also tells Judas to stop his sacrifices,
for the stars and angels have already completed everything.
In that moment, Judas felt a profound confusion but also connection with Yeshua,
a bond that transcended time, space and understanding. He understood that his role,
though shrouded in darkness, was essential to the unfolding of a divine plan.
As the first light of dawn began to creep into the garden, Jesus and Judas returned
to the waiting disciples. The others sensed a change, an unspoken understanding that had
passed between the two men. They did not question it, for until after the crucifixion of Jesus, for
they where witnesses to a cosmic drama that their primitive mortal minds could not comprehend.
And so, Judas Iscariot, with a heavy heart and unwavering resolve, set in motion the events that
would lead to Yeshua's crucifixion. His actions, condemned by the disciples became widespread.
In the annals of time, Judas's name would be forever tarnished, yet it is believed that his
wife would later become a Gnostic Christian who helped record the Gospel of Judas in the Dead Sea
Scrolls. The Gnostics viewed Judas's sacrifice as an event hidden by the realms of the divine and
the Roman Church. For in the grand library of all existence, even the darkest threads are woven with
purpose. In this gospel, we also see another side of Jesus—a side that is more spiritual
and revolutionary, one that many powerful elites and empires have sought to suppress. These texts
confirm Jesus's revolutionary, intellectual, and spiritual mindset, showcasing the duality of man.
Thus, the tale of Yeshua and Judas unfolds, a testament to the complexities of faith,
the mysteries of the cosmos, and the profound bonds that unite us all in the
journey of life and beyond. If you would like to know more about these subjects,
please read the complete Apocrypha and Nag Hammadi gospels, which are Gnostic texts that predate the
modern Bible and were excluded by the Vatican. Let us know what you think about the Gospel of
Judas. Is it all fabricated by the Gnostic Christians? Were the Romans right to exclude
this gospel and portray Judas as a villain? Was Jesus really an alien from another realm,
or is the text suggesting something deeper? Please share your thoughts in the comments.
